questions.text: 50-year-old male develops a headache, light headedness, nausea and dizziness after working on his car in the garage.  His wife suspects CO poisoning and brings him to the emergency. The patient’s skin is red; he does not appear to be in respiratory distress and denies dyspnoea. Blood levels of carboxyhaemoglobin are elevated. Which of the following best explains the absence of respiratory signs and symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Arterial oxygen tension is normal 
CO poisoning decreases the arterial oxygen saturation and thus the total arterial oxygen content, but it does not reduce the dissolved oxygen. CO poisoning produces anemic hypoxia, where the arterial oxygen content is reduced but the arterial oxygen tension is normal. Normal PaO2 does not stimulate the peripheral chemoreceptors explaining the absence of respiratory signs and symptoms. Respiratory distress in CO poisoning is a late sign. Respiratory distress becomes manifest with severe tissue hypoxia and anerobic glycolysis, which leads to lactic acidosis. The decrease in arterial pH stimulates ventilation via the peripheral chemoreceptors.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with severe sepsis is admitted to the ICU. His serum creatinine rises from 1.1 mg/dL to 3.5 mg/dL over 24 hours. The team initiates broad-spectrum antibiotics, including one that does NOT require dose adjustment in renal failure. Which antibiotic fits this profile?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ceftriaxone

Explanation:
Most antibiotics are cleared renally and require dose reduction in renal impairment to prevent toxicity.
•    Vancomycin → cleared renally; needs dose adjustment.
•    Amikacin (aminoglycoside) → cleared renally; very nephrotoxic if not adjusted.
•    Imipenem → cleared renally; needs adjustment to avoid neurotoxicity.
•    Ceftriaxone → uniquely eliminated mainly through the biliary system; thus, renal impairment has minimal effect on its clearance, and no dose adjustment is typically needed.

questions.text: The drug used for reverse use-dependence in cardiac arrhythmia is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dofetilide

Amiodarone → class III with multi-channel effects; minimal reverse use-dependence, works consistently across heart rates.
Sotalol → class III and β-blocker; shows reverse use-dependence but less purely than dofetilide.
 Flecainide → class IC sodium channel blocker; use-dependent (stronger block at higher rates), not reverse use-dependent.
Dofetilide → pure class III K⁺ channel blocker; classic example of reverse use-dependence, prolonging repolarization most at slow heart rates, which can paradoxically increase the risk of torsades de pointes during bradycardia.

questions.text: A non-steroidal immunosuppressant inhibiting guanosine nucleotide synthesis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mycophenolate mofetil
•    Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF):
→ A non-steroidal immunosuppressant.
→ Inhibits inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), an enzyme crucial for de novo guanosine nucleotide synthesis.
→ Selectively affects T and B lymphocytes because they rely heavily on this pathway (whereas other cells can use the salvage pathway).
→ Used in solid organ transplantation, autoimmune diseases like lupus nephritis.
→ Side effects: GI upset, leukopenia, teratogenicity.
________________________________________
Why not the others?
•    Azathioprine:
→ A purine analog prodrug converted to 6-mercaptopurine; broadly inhibits purine synthesis but not specific to guanosine.
•    Cyclosporine:
→ A calcineurin inhibitor; blocks IL-2 transcription, inhibiting T-cell activation.
•    Sirolimus (rapamycin):
→ mTOR inhibitor; blocks response to IL-2, halting T-cell proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following antiepileptic drugs acts mainly by modulating SV2A vesicle protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Levetiracetam

Levetiracetam →
✅ Binds to SV2A (Synaptic Vesicle Protein 2A), a protein involved in synaptic vesicle exocytosis.
✅ Modulates neurotransmitter release (particularly glutamate and GABA) by reducing excessive synaptic activity.
✅ Does not significantly affect sodium or calcium channels, nor GABA metabolism.
✅ Broad-spectrum use: focal and generalized epilepsy, myoclonic seizures.
✅ Favorable pharmacokinetics: minimal drug interactions, no hepatic enzyme induction.
✅ Side effects: mood changes, irritability, somnolence.
________________________________________
Why not the others?
•    Lamotrigine → blocks voltage-gated sodium channels; decreases glutamate release.
•    Phenytoin → blocks voltage-gated sodium channels; use-dependent effect.
•    Valproate → increases GABA levels, blocks sodium channels, and has some T-type calcium channel effects.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman receiving chemotherapy for colorectal cancer develops painful redness, swelling, and peeling on her palms and soles, consistent with hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia). Which of the following anticancer agents is most commonly associated with this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

5-Fluorouracil

Detailed Explanation:
•    5-Fluorouracil (5-FU):
✅ A pyrimidine analog antimetabolite used in colorectal, breast, gastric, and pancreatic cancers.
✅ Can cause hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia), characterized by redness, swelling, pain, and sometimes blistering on the palms and soles.
✅ Mechanism: local leakage of the drug from capillaries in areas of repeated pressure or friction, leading to skin toxicity.
✅ Capecitabine, an oral prodrug of 5-FU, is even more strongly associated with this syndrome.
________________________________________
Why not the others?
•    Doxorubicin: → causes cardiotoxicity (dose-dependent dilated cardiomyopathy), not hand-foot syndrome.
•    Vincristine: → neurotoxicity (peripheral neuropathy), jaw pain, constipation.
•    Methotrexate: → mucositis, hepatotoxicity, myelosuppression.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lab worker presents with sudden confusion, dyspnea, flushed skin, and severe lactic acidosis after accidental exposure to cyanide gas. The medical team prepares the antidotal regimen. Which of the following agents is NOT used as part of cyanide poisoning treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Deferoxamine

Detailed Explanation:
•    Cyanide poisoning antidotes include:
✅ Hydroxocobalamin → binds cyanide to form cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12), which is renally excreted.
✅ Sodium thiosulfate → acts as a sulfur donor to convert cyanide to thiocyanate (non-toxic, excreted).
✅ Amyl nitrite (and sodium nitrite) → induces methemoglobinemia, which binds cyanide away from cytochrome oxidase.

Why not deferoxamine?
•    Deferoxamine is an iron chelator used in iron overdose, NOT in cyanide poisoning. It has no role in cyanide detoxification.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with hyperthyroidism is started on a drug that inhibiting the Na⁺/I⁻ symporter, effectively reducing thyroid hormone synthesis. Which of the following agents acts by this mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Perchlorate

Detailed Explanation:
•    Perchlorate (and thiocyanate):
✅ Competitively inhibit the Na⁺/I⁻ symporter on the basolateral membrane of thyroid follicular cells.
✅ This blocks the uptake of iodide from the bloodstream into the gland, decreasing thyroid hormone synthesis upstream.
✅ Rarely used now due to risk of aplastic anemia.
________________________________________
Why not the others?
•    Methimazole & Propylthiouracil (PTU):
→ Inhibit thyroid peroxidase (TPO), blocking iodide organification and coupling, not the symporter.
→ PTU additionally inhibits peripheral T₄ → T₃ conversion.
•    Lugol’s iodine:
→ High-dose iodine preparation; inhibits thyroid hormone release (Wolff–Chaikoff effect), not iodide uptake.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with liver disease is receiving a drug known to have a high hepatic extraction ratio. The team is concerned about how his altered physiology will affect drug clearance. For such a drug, which factor primarily determines its clearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Liver blood flow

Detailed Explanation:
•    High extraction ratio drugs (e.g., propranolol, lidocaine, verapamil, morphine):
✅ Their hepatic clearance depends mainly on how much drug is delivered to the liver per unit time, i.e., liver blood flow.
✅ This is because the liver removes most of the drug as it passes through (extraction ratio > 0.7).
✅ Changes in enzyme activity or protein binding have little effect because the system is flow-limited, not capacity-limited.
________________________________________
Why not the others?
•    Protein binding: Affects only drugs with low extraction ratios (capacity-limited, sensitive to free drug levels).
•    Hepatic enzyme activity: Important for low-extraction drugs, where metabolism depends on enzyme capacity.
•    Biliary excretion: Refers to elimination route, not clearance rate determinant.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, approved in late 2024, is a first-in-class antisense oligonucleotide targeting apolipoprotein C-III mRNA for the treatment of familial chylomicronemia syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Olezarsen

Detailed Explanation:
•    Olezarsen:
✅ FDA-approved in December 2024.
✅ Antisense oligonucleotide designed to bind and degrade ApoC-III mRNA, reducing ApoC-III protein levels, which helps lower triglycerides and reduce chylomicron buildup.
✅ Used specifically for familial chylomicronemia syndrome (FCS), a rare disorder characterized by extreme hypertriglyceridemia and risk of pancreatitis.
________________________________________
Why not the others?
•    Inclisiran: → siRNA drug targeting PCSK9 mRNA for lowering LDL cholesterol, not triglycerides.
•    Mipomersen: → antisense oligonucleotide targeting ApoB-100 mRNA for homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia.
•    Evinacumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting ANGPTL3 (angiopoietin-like 3). ANGPTL3 normally inhibits lipoprotein lipase (LPL) and endothelial lipase, enzymes that break down triglycerides and lipoproteins.

questions.text: In March 2024, the FDA approved the fixed-dose combination of xanomeline and trospium chloride (brand name Cobenfy™) for the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Schizophrenia

Detailed Explanation:
•    Xanomeline:
✅ A selective muscarinic M₁/M₄ receptor agonist that modulates central cholinergic pathways implicated in psychosis.
✅ Reduces both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia.
•    Trospium chloride:
✅ A peripherally acting muscarinic antagonist added to block peripheral cholinergic side effects (like bradycardia, GI upset) without interfering with central effects.

Why not the others?
•    Sjögren’s syndrome: Autoimmune condition, treated with symptomatic agents and immunosuppressants.
•    COPD: Managed with bronchodilators and anti-inflammatory agents.
•    OAB (Overactive bladder): Treated with antimuscarinic agents like trospium alone, but not this combination.

questions.text: A surgical instrument is sterilized by an autoclave at 121°C under 15 psi for 15 minutes. What is the primary mechanism of sterilization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This effectively kills bacteria, spores, and viruses. 

Oxidation is the mechanism of dry heat sterilization, alkylation is used by ethylene oxide gas, and dehydration is used by desiccation.

questions.text: The image given below is of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Haddon’s matrix
Explanation
The Haddon Matrix is a framework developed by Dr. William Haddon, Jr., in the 1970s, used to analyse injury and accident prevention strategies. It's a grid-like structure that helps organize factors influencing an event, including pre-event, event, and post-event phases, alongside host, agent/vehicle, physical environment, and social environment factors. 
Key Components of the Haddon Matrix: 
•    Phases of an Event:
•    Pre-Event: Factors leading up to the event, such as risk factors or interventions to prevent the event from occurring. 
•    Event: Factors during the event, such as the type of energy transfer or the severity of the impact. 
•    Post-Event: Factors after the event, such as emergency response or medical care. 
•    Factors Influencing the Event:
•    Host: The individual involved (e.g., pedestrian, driver). 
•    Agent/Vehicle: The object or energy source (e.g., car, bicycle, water). 
•    Physical Environment: The surrounding physical setting (e.g., road, building, water). 
•    Social Environment: Societal norms and laws influencing behaviour (e.g., seatbelt laws, drinking and driving policies). 
The Haddon Matrix helps to: 
•    Identify Risk Factors: By analysing each cell of the matrix, you can identify factors contributing to an injury or accident.
•    Develop Prevention Strategies: The matrix provides a framework for developing interventions tailored to specific phases and factors.
•    Assess Interventions: You can evaluate the effectiveness of prevention strategies by considering how they address different phases and factors.
•    Collect Data: The matrix can guide data collection efforts by focusing on relevant factors and phases.

questions.text: Which anatomical structure is most at risk during surgical drainage of a parapharyngeal abscess?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Internal carotid artery
Ref:Read the text below
Sol:-
Surgical drainage of a parapharyngeal abscess requires careful consideration of these structures.
1.    Internal Carotid Artery (ICA) is at the highest risk:
o    The ICA runs posterior and lateral within the parapharyngeal space.
o    Infections in this space can lead to inflammatory weakening of the vessel wall, 
2.    Why not the other options?
o    Hypoglossal nerve (A) (CN XII): Located more inferiorly in the neck and less commonly affected by a parapharyngeal abscess.
o    Vagus nerve (C) (CN X): It runs within the carotid sheath but is less prone to direct injury compared to the ICA.
o    Superior laryngeal nerve (D): More laterally positioned and less frequently compromised during abscess drainage.
Clinical Implication:
•    Injury to the internal carotid artery can result in massive hemorrhage, stroke, or death.
•    Careful preoperative imaging (CT angiography) and proper surgical technique are essential to avoid complications.

choices.text: Endoscopic sinus surgery with complete polypectomy

questions.text:
A 16-year-old male presents with progressive unilateral nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and occasional epistaxis for the past 6 months. Examination reveals a grayish polypoidal mass in the nasopharynx. Contrast-enhanced CT scan shows a soft-tissue mass originating from the maxillary sinus, extending into the choana and nasopharynx, without bony destruction.
Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Endoscopic sinus surgery with complete polypectomy
Ref:Read the text below
Sol:-
•    This case is highly suggestive of an Antrochoanal Polyp (Killian Polyp) due to its unilateral presentation, nasal obstruction, and nasopharyngeal extension without bony destruction.
•    Corticosteroids (Option A) are ineffective because AC polyp is not eosinophilic/inflammatory like allergic polyps.
•    Biopsy & chemoradiotherapy (Option C) would be needed for malignancy (e.g., nasopharyngeal carcinoma), but this case lacks high-risk features like lymph node involvement.
•    Caldwell-Luc procedure (Option D) is outdated and not preferred for AC polyps due to its invasiveness and risk of complications.
Gold Standard Treatment:
Endoscopic sinus surgery (ESS) with complete removal of the polyp, including its antral portion to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 42 year old patient complains of easy fatiguability of voice.Indirect laryngoscopy shows elliptical space between the cords. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis?

It is weakness of voice due to fatigue of phonatory muscles.
Indirect laryngoscopy shows three characteristic findings:
     Elliptical space -- thyroarytenoid.
     Triangular gap -- interarytenoid.
     Key-hole appearance of glottis when both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoids are involved.
Treatment is voice rest 
•    Mogiophonia is speech defect in public appearance only.
•    Rhinolalia clausa is hyponasality. This is due to nasal obstruction, nasal polyp, sinusitis, adenoid hypertrophy, angiofibroma.
•    Rhinolalia aperta is hypernasality. This is due to cleft palate,palatal perforation,palatal palsy.
•    In adductor spasmodic dysphonia, patient has choked voive ( strangulated voice).
•    In abductor SD, the voice is breathy.

questions.text: The rare complication of atlantoaxial subluxation seen after adenotonsillectomy is known as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Grisel syndrome

Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
•    Grisel's syndrome is a nontraumatic atlantoaxial subluxation which is usually secondary of an infection or an inflammation at the head and neck region. 
•    It can be observed after surgery of head and neck region. 
•    Etiopathogenesis has not been clearly described yet, but increased looseness of paraspinal ligament is thought to be responsible. 
•    Patients typically present with painful torticollis. 
•    Diagnosis of Grisel's syndrome is largely based on suspicion of the patient who has recently underwent surgery or history of infection in head and neck region. 
•    Physical examination and imaging techniques assist in diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy presents with severe dyspnea and bilateral inspiratory rales. What is the appropriate pharmacologic management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

β-adrenergic blocker 

•    Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by asymmetric left ventricular hypertophy resulting in impaired relaxation and left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.
•    Maneuvers or pharmacologic agents that decrease preload (or increase chronotropy) will increase LVOT obstruction, thus worsening pulmonary congestion.
•    The cornerstone of therapy is decreased chronotropy to allow for increased diastolic filling time of the noncompliant left ventricle.
•    The end result is a decrease in both LVOT obstruction and pulmonary venous congestion.
•    Nitroglycerin, Nesiritide, and morphine will cause a reduction in preload and thus likely worsen the patient's clinical status.

questions.text: Variant Angina is characterised by all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Variant Angina is the other term for Prinz metal’s angina which is a result of coronary vasospasm. It most commonly affects middle aged females and is poorly related to exertion. It typically occurs in sleep between 12-5am.  30% cases maybe associated with other vasospastic disorders like migraine and Raynaud’s phenomenon. Attacks are usually precipitated by emotional stress/smoking/cocaine and amphetamine. ECG can show transient ST-T changes (elevation) suggesting Myocardial ischemia. Coronary angiography may reveal normal arteries. However, 50-60% may harbour significant coronary stenosis. Hence, provocative testing with ergonovine/intra-coronary acetylcholine is mandatory during angiography to demonstrate vasospasm. The treatment consists of Nitrates and CCB. Beta-blockers are best avoided because they may precipitate vasospasm by facilitating un-opposed alpha-action. Prognosis is excellent with <1% mortality.

questions.text: A post-menopausal female presented with sudden onset angina. Coronary Angiography revealed normal vessels. Ventriculography performed in this patient during systole revealed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy – Stress induced cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart syndrome) is a unknown etiology transient myocardial ischemia syndrome common in postmenopausal females especially after intense emotional stimulus. Patients often present with chest pain, have ST-segment elevation on electrocardiography (ECG), and have elevated cardiac enzyme levels consistent with myocardial infarction (MI). However, when the patient undergoes cardiac angiography, left ventricular (LV) apical ballooning (as seen in the Question image – Takotsubo) is present, and there is no significant coronary artery stenosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female non-smoker presented with sudden onset of cough followed by breathlessness. CXR revealed pneumothorax. She also gives history of similar episodes in the past. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pulmonary LAM 
•    Pulmonary Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a rare, progressive and systemic disease that typically results in cystic lung destruction. 
•    It predominantly affects women, especially during childbearing years.
•    It is a neoplasm of smooth muscle spindle. 
•    Majority present with shortness of breath with recurrent spontaneous pneumothorax in a non-smoker female. 
•    Sirolimus is an mTOR inhibitor that stabilizes lung function and improves some measures of life in LAM patients. 
•    Lung transplant offers potential cure but there is a risk of recurrence in the graft making the overall prognosis poor.

questions.text: True regarding pseudohypoparathyroidism include all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pseudohypoparathyroidism is genetic disorder characterized by symptoms and signs of hypoparathyroidism, typically in association with distinctive skeletal and developmental defects. The hypoparathyroidism is due to a deficient end-organ response to PTH. Hyperplasia of the parathyroid, a response to hormone resistance, causes elevation of PTH levels. 
Most patients show characteristic features of Albright dystrophy, consisting of short stature, round face, skeletal anomalies (brachydactyly), and heterotopic calcification. Patients have low calcium and high phosphate levels, as with true hypoparathyroidism. PTH levels, however, are elevated, reflecting resistance to hormone action.

questions.text: Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is characterized by all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hypercalcemia

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is an oncologic emergency that is caused by massive tumor cell lysis with the release of large amounts of potassium, phosphate, and nucleic acids into the systemic circulation. The metabolic consequences include hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, secondary hypocalcemia, hyperuricemia, and acute kidney injury. High levels of both uric acid and phosphate increase the severity of acute kidney injury because uric acid precipitates readily in the presence of calcium phosphate crystals, and calcium phosphate precipitates readily in the presence of uric acid crystals.

questions.text:
A 60year old woman is admitted with sudden onset of chest pain and is diagnosed with an acute myocardial infarction. Her acute illness is complicated by low blood pressure and poor tissue perfusion for several days. Her serum Urea and Creatinine are noted to be increasing. On day 1 – Urea – 8, Creatinine – 1.16

•    c) Nodular glomerulosclerosis – Seen in diabetic nephropathy, causes chronic kidney disease, not acute AKI.

questions.text: Michelis Gutamen bodies are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Malacoplakia (Greek- Soft plaque)
•    Malacoplakia is an inflammatory disease that affect the bladder but has been found to affect the genitourinary and gastrointestinal tracts, skin, lungs, bones, and mesenteric lymph nodes. (Described by Michaelis and Gutmann)
•    It is characterized by von Hansemann as soft, yellow-brown plaques with granulomatous lesions in which the histiocytes contain distinct basophilic inclusions or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.
•    Malacoplakia probably results from abnormal macrophage function in response to a bacterial infection, which is most often E. coli. Common in immunodeficiency syndrome, autoimmune disease, carcinoma, or another systemic disorder
•    There is inadequate killing of bacteria by macrophages due to defective phagolysosomal activity.
•    It is hypothesized that bacteria or bacterial fragments form the nidus for the calcium phosphate crystals that laminate the Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. 
•    Septran and Quinoline are drug of choice
•    For severe cases Surgery may be required. Bilateral renal involvement is poor prognostic and mortality is high

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with problems with eating. She reports that over the past few months, she has experienced some difficulty swallowing food. She drinks liquids normally, but has difficulty swallowing solid foods. On endoscopy there is a exophytic mass in the cervical esophagus. Which on biopsy was diagnosed as SCC. She was treated by Chemoradiotherapy. Due to persistence of symptoms further esophagectomy was done, The technique of resecting an esophageal cancer which remains symptomatic after definitive chemoradiotherapy is referred to as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Salvage esophagectomy is the nomenclature applied to esophagectomy performed after failure of definitive radiation and chemotherapy. The most frequent scenario is one in which distant disease (bone, lung, brain, or wide LN metastases) renders the patient nonoperable at initial presentation. Then, systemic chemotherapy, usually with radiation of the primary tumor, destroys all foci of metastasis, as demonstrated by CT and CT-PET, but the primary remains present and symptomatic. Following a period of observation, to make sure no new disease will become evident, salvage esophagectomy is performed, usually with an open two-field approach. Surprisingly, the cure rate of salvage esophagectomy is not inconsequential. One in four patients undergoing this operation will be disease free 5 years later, despite the presence of residual cancer in the operative specimen. Because of the dense scarring created by radiation treatment, this procedure is the most technically challenging of all esophagectomy techniques

questions.text:
According to CDC classification which of the following is not a type of Class 3 wound?
1: Dry gangrene 
2: Interval appendicectomy
3: Accidental bowel perforation during laparotomy
4: Perianal abscess
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

(1 and 3 are class 3 wound)

Class 1 wounds- Clean: An uninfected surgical wound in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts are not entered.
•    Uninfected, no inflammation, Resp, GI, GU tracts not entered
•    Closed primarily
•    Examples: Ex lap, mastectomy, neck dissection, thyroid, vascular, hernia, splenectomy
Class 2 wounds- Clean-contaminated: A surgical wound in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts are entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination.
•    Resp, GI, GU tracts entered, controlled
•    No unusual contamination
•    Examples: Chole, SBR, Whipple, liver txp, gastric surgery, bronch, colon surgery
Class 3 wound- III: Contaminated: — Open, fresh, accidental wounds. Surgical procedures in which a major break in sterile technique occurs or there is gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered. 
•    Open, fresh, accidental wounds
•    Major break in sterile technique
•    Gross Spillage from GI tract
•    Acute nonpurulent inflammation
•    Examples: Inflamed appy, bile spillage in chole, diverticulitis, Rectal surgery, penetrating wounds
Class 4 wound- IV: Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained or devitalized tissue and those that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera.
•    Old traumatic wounds, devitalized tissue
•    Existing infection or perforation
•    Organisms present BEFORE procedure
•    Examples: Abscess I&D, wet gangrene, perforated bowel, peritonitis, wound debridement, positive cultures pre-op

questions.text: Which of the following is best suture for subcuticular stiches?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Monocryl

Monocryl is a synthetic, absorbable suture composed of poliglecaprone, which is a copolymer of glycolide and epsilon-caprolactone. It comes both dyed (violet) and undyed (clear) and is an absorbable monofilament suture. Dyed monocryl retains 30–40% of its tensile strength at 2 weeks whereas undyed monocryl retains only 25% at 2 weeks. By 3 weeks, there is no residual strength, absorption is by hydrolysis and is complete by 90–120 days.

The CDC describes 3 types of surgical site infections:

•    Deep incisional SSI. This infection occurs beneath the incision area in muscle and the tissues surrounding the muscles.
•    Organ or space SSI. This type of infection can be in any area of the body other than skin, muscle, and surrounding tissue that was involved in the surgery. This includes a body organ or a space between organs.

questions.text: A patient underwent all 4 parathyroidectomy and fragment implnatation in left forearm muscle for parathyroid hyperplasia. questions.text: A 20 year old man presents with pain in the thigh. Pain is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin. X ray demonstrates a bone lesion. What Is the lesion?

Radiographic features (as seen in the image):

questions.text: A 56 year old post menopausal women is on Ibandronate 150 mg once a month for last 48 months. Now she complains of vague pain in and around the hip. What's the next investigation to be done in her to probe further into what's happening?

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the following X ray:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
The X-ray shows a lytic, expansile lesion in the epiphyseal region of the distal radius (near the wrist joint), with a well-defined margin, and no sclerotic border. These features are classic for Giant Cell Tumor (GCT)
Key Radiological Features of GCT:
•    Eccentric, lytic lesion in the epiphysis of long bones
•    Often extends to subchondral bone (near joint surface)
•    "Soap-bubble" appearance due to internal trabeculations
•    Common in distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius

questions.text: A patient came with history of RTA and shaft of femur fracture. Patient was stabilized. After 72 hours, he developed sudden onset breathlessness, confusion and petechial skin rashes over axilla and chest. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) is a serious complication that can occur after long bone fractures (especially the femur), orthopaedic surgeries, or trauma. It typically presents within 12–72 hours after the injury.
Classic Triad of Fat Embolism Syndrome:
1.    Respiratory distress – breathlessness, hypoxia, tachypnea
2.    Neurological symptoms – confusion, agitation, seizures, or coma
3.    Petechial rash – often seen on the chest, axillae, conjunctivae, or upper arms
These findings are highly suggestive of fat embolism, especially in the setting of a long bone fracture like the femur.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man American association anaesthesiology class-III (ASA-III) with a history of coronary artery disease, chronic renal disease, and obstructive sleep apnea is taken to the operating room for inguinal hernia repair. He had been seen by a cardiologist and cleared for surgery. General anesthesia via LMA is considered with maintenance using desflurane. Vital signs are normal prior to pre-op, and induction and placement of the LMA are uneventful. Ten minutes later, during surgical prep, the patient's vital signs show HR 115/min, BP 148/96 mmHg, RR 14/min, ETCO2 40 mmhg & SpO2 99%. The end-tidal desflurane value reads 8.5, and the only other medication administered at this point was cefazolin. What is the most likely cause for the patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    Desflurane, especially when rapidly titrated, will stimulate the sympathetic nervous system.
•    A higher flow rate on the anesthesia machine can lead to an increase in the fraction of inspired volatile, which will yield more rapid titration of anesthetic. This rapid change in end-tidal volatile, rather than a slow titration, can increase HR and BP transiently.
•    In this patient with a history of CAD, sympathetic stimulation should be avoided to prevent further ischemia.
•    While desflurane is a malignant hyperthermia triggering agent, it is unlikely given the patient's modest elevation in EtCO2, which is more likely explained by his history of OSA. The elevation in HR and BP are non-specific, and it would be much more likely to malignant hyperthermia with a much more rapid elevation in EtCO2. 
•    The non-specific nature of isolated tachycardia and hypertension are much more commonly associated with rapid titration of desflurane as opposed to MH in this scenario. 
•    Inadequate depth of anesthesia certainly presents as hypertension and tachycardia. However, it is much less likely in this scenario where the patient has no surgical stimulation yet as the prep is ongoing, and it has been 10 minutes since the stimulation of placing the LMA occurred. 
•    In addition, the patient's MAC is > 1, which is more than adequate given the lack of stimulation at this time. In fact, it is because of the rapid titration of the volatile agent desflurane which likely led to the tachycardia and hypertension. 
•    Allergic or anaphylactic reactions are common with steroidal non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking drugs as well as perioperative antibiotics. 
•    However, it is much more commonly associated with hypotension, tachycardia, and increased peak airway pressures. 
•    The Etiology of this patient's tachycardia and hypertension are much more likely caused by sympathetic stimulation from desflurane. The mechanism by which the sympathetic stimulation occurs is not fully understood, but rapid titration tends to increase the incidence of stimulation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, heavy smoker, with COPD is having micro laryngeal surgery under general anaesthesia. He is intubated and ventilated. During the procedure, his saturation on pulse oximeter start to dip and he develops an expiratory wheeze, and it is getting difficult to ventilate. Which of the statements below is the most appropriate in the immediate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•    This patient has developed significant bronchospasm.
•    Bronchospasm occurs when smooth muscle in the conducting airways contracts, as a result of irritability (smokers, asthmatics, volatile anaesthetics),or light plane of anaesthesia.
•    Where bronchospasm is suspected, high-flow oxygen should be delivered and anaesthesia deepened using a non-irritant volatile (sevoflurane, halothane) or intravenous anaesthetic.
•    Use of short acting bronchodilators i.e. beta 2 agonists like salbutamol intra tracheal or intravenous are highly effective. 
•    Intravenous corticosteroids act more slowly to suppress the underlying inflammatory processes and may be appropriate depending on the cause. 
•    Ventilation using reduced tidal volumes may be required to protect against barotrauma
•    In a patient with high risk of bronchospasm use of a Laryngeal Mask Airway causes less irritation of the airway and so less chances of development of bronchospasm but in this case it’s a microlaryngeal surgery and so LMA can’t be used as an airway.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman says that when she is under stress, she often feels as if she is “outside of herself” and is watching her life as though it were a play. She knows that this perception is only a feeling and that she is really living her life. This woman is showing evidence of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Depersonalization disorder

This woman, who feels as if she is “outside of herself,” watching her life as though it were a play, is showing evidence of depersonalization disorder, a persistent feeling of detachment from one’s own body or the social situation. In contrast to psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia, this woman is aware that this perception is only a feeling and that she is really living her life.

questions.text: Catastrophic reaction is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dementia 

(Ref : Kaplan Psychiatry Pg 714) 
Catastrophic Reaction. Patients with dementia also exhibit a reduced ability to apply what Kurt Goldstein called the “abstract attitude.” Patients have difficulty generalizing from a single instance, forming concepts, and grasping similarities and differences among concepts. Furthermore, the ability to solve problems, to reason logically, and to make sound judgments is compromised. Goldstein also described a catastrophic reaction marked by agitation secondary to the subjective awareness of intellectual deficits under stressful circumstances. Persons usually attempt to compensate for defects by using strategies to avoid demonstrating failures in intellectual performance; they may change the subject, make jokes, or otherwise divert the interviewer. Lack of judgment and poor impulse control appear commonly, particularly in dementias that primarily affect the frontal lobes. Examples of these impairments include coarse language, inappropriate jokes, neglect of personal appearance and hygiene, and a general disregard for the conventional rules of social conduct.

questions.text: All of the following drugs should be withdrawn before administering ECT (Electroconvulsive therapy) except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

(Tricyclic antidepressants) 

(Ref : Kaplan Psychiatry Pg 1068) 
Patients’ ongoing medications should be assessed for possible interactions with the induction of a seizure, for effects (both positive and negative) on the seizure threshold, and for drug interactions with the medications used during ECT. The use of tricyclic and tetracyclic drugs, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, and antipsychotics is generally considered acceptable. Benzodiazepines used for anxiety should be withdrawn because of their anticonvulsant activity; lithium should be withdrawn because it can result in increased postictal delirium and can prolong seizure activity; clozapine and bupropion should be withdrawn because they are associated with the development of late-appearing seizures.

questions.text: The major neurotransmitter system involved in development of substance abuse and substance dependence is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dopaminergic neurons from ventral tegmental area to nucleus accumbens 

(Ref : Kaplan Psychiatry Pg 621) 

The major neurotransmitters possibly involved in developing substance abuse and substance dependence are the opioid, catecholamine (particularly dopamine), and γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) systems. The dopaminergic neurons in the ventral tegmental area are particularly important. These neurons project to the cortical and limbic regions, especially the nucleus accumbens. This pathway is probably involved in the sensation of reward and may be the major mediator of the effects of such substances as amphetamine and cocaine. The locus ceruleus, the largest group of adrenergic neurons, probably mediates the effects of the opiates and the opioids. These pathways have collectively been called the brain-reward circuitry.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician with the complaint that his memory has worsened over the past 2 months and that he has difficulty concentrating. He has lost interest in his friends and his work. He has difficulty with abstract thoughts and problem solving. He has also felt depressed. MRI scan shows parenchymal abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HIV-related dementia 

HIV dementia is the most frequent neurological complication of HIV infection and can be the first symptom of the infection. It is caused by a direct effect of the virus on the brain and is always accompanied by some brain atrophy. HIV dementia presents with the combination of cognitive impairment, motor deficits, and behavioral changes typical of a subcortical dementia. Common features include impaired attention and concentration, psychomotor slowing, forgetfulness, slow reaction time, and mood changes.

questions.text: A 55 years old P2L2 has come with a history of post-menopausal bleeding since last 3 months. On examination, her cervix and vagina appeared normal. She has no other complaints. What is the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

PAP and TVS

In order to identify the cause of postmenopausal bleeding in this case where cervix and vagina are appearing healthy and normal, we must do transvaginal sonography as well as Pap smear. If transvaginal scan shows increased endometrial thickness (more than 4mm) then we must do endometrial aspiration or biopsy.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not used in a case of menopausal symptom of vaginal dryness and dyspareunia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Danazol

Vaginal dryness and dyspareunia would be qualified as urogenital syndrome. It is due to estrogen deficiency. Treatment of choice is locally estrogen or vaginal moisturizers. Ospemifene is estrogenic on vagina so it is also useful. Danazol is anti-estrogenic drug and it is not meant for this indication.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs will be used in the treatment of Sheehan’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Corticosteroids

In a case of Sheehan syndrome, there is pituitary apoplexy. We must give corticosteroids because there is hypotension caused by ACTH deficiency. GnRH therapy or anti estrogenic therapy for ovulation induction would not work in a case of Sheehan syndrome.

choices.text: Closing the subcutaneous tissue during abdominal hysterectomy
Closing the blind space during abdominal myomectomy

questions.text: Which one of the following is not an indication of using the following suture material?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cervical cerclage

This is chromic catgut. It is an absorbable suture material. It is never used in a case of cervical cerclage. For cervical cerclage operation, we use non-absorbable suture material like mersilene or nylon.

questions.text: A 45 years old patient presented with complaints of pain and abdomen and menorrhagia since last 9 months. Endometrial biopsy was normal and sonography of uterus revealed uniformly enlarged uterus with no adnexal mass and no focal lesion in the myometrium. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Adenomyosis 

No focal lesion in myometrium would mean that there is no evidence of fibroid. Endometrial biopsy is normal, so there is no chance of endometrial cancer. Uterus is enlarged and there is no adnexal mass, so it cannot be endometriosis. This is the case of adenomyosis which usually presents with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a reason for prolapse of uterus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cesarean sections 

Smoking leads to damage of collagenous tissue hence it is a risk factor for uterine prolapse. Collagen vascular disease like Ehler Danlos syndrome can also cause prolapse. Any abdomino-pelvic tumour can cause traction pressure effect and hence there is a chance of prolapse. Multiple vaginal deliveries can lead to injury to the support system and hence there is a chance of prolapse. Cesarean sections would be protective against prolapse of uterus.

questions.text: A 52 years old female P2L2 with postmenopausal bleeding had endometrial biopsy report suggestive of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. What should be the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mirena

Endometrial hyperplasia without atypia should be treated by medical management. The drug of choice is progesterone. Mirena is levonorgestrel intrauterine device. It will provide progesterone for the period of five years. Hence it is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 33 years old nulliparous patient has AUB-L with FIGO type 2 fibroid of 7 cm. She is also suffering from PCOS and wants to conceive. What is the right plan of action for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Laparoscopic myomectomy followed by letrozole

Symptomatic fibroid must be treated. Myomectomy is done laparoscopically for all types of fibroid except FIGO-0 and FIGO-1. Hence in this case, we must do laparoscopic myomectomy and then we must do ovulation induction by letrozole therapy. Letrozole therapy is the drug of choice in PCOS patient.

questions.text: A person is genotypically male, phenotypically female and has presence of Mullerian structures. This is possible in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Swyer syndrome

Genotypically male, phenotypically female with presence of Mullerian structures would mean gonadal dysgenesis. Swyer syndrome is a case of pure gonadal dysgenesis. There is SRY gene mutation and hence testicular formation does not happen.

questions.text: In a post-menopausal patient, having vasomotor symptoms, which of the following drugs has potential harm for causing the same symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ospemifene

Ospemifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. It is estrogenic on vagina and hence it is used for vaginal dryness and dyspareunia. However, it is anti-estrogenic on vasomotor centers and hence it may cause hot flushes.

choices.text: Poor prognosis as compared to type 2 cancer

questions.text: A 60 years old post-menopausal patient has endometrial cancer. Which of the following character corresponds to Type 1 endometrial cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Estrogen excess

There are two types of endometrial cancer. Type 1 cancer has better prognosis and type 2 cancer has poorer prognosis. Type 1 cancer is seen in patients with estrogen-excess. These patients are typically obese. Type 2 cancer is seen in estrogen-deficient patients and these patients are typically thin patients with p53 mutation.

questions.text: Which one of the following clinical condition requires treatment with the following device?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stress urinary incontinence

This is a ring pessary with a knob. The knob is meant to give support to the bladder-base and urethra. It will help in avoiding bladder-neck hyper mobility. So, it is used in cases of stress urinary incontinence.

questions.text: The most common complication arising from a mature cystic teratoma of ovary is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Torsion

Mature cystic teratoma of ovaries is nothing but dermoid cyst of ovary. It is known to have sebaceous material which leads to reduced density of the tumour and hence there is a chance of torsion in this case. It is the most common complication of dermoid. It causes acute pain in abdomen.

questions.text: A 32 years old nulliparous patient had molar pregnancy which was treated by suction evacuation. She was kept under surveillance and her HCG was evaluated every week. The most specific characteristic feature of the development of gestational choriocarcinoma amongst the following is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bluish green vaginal nodule

Gestational choriocarcinoma will have rising HCG values. There may be metastasis to different organs. Bluish vaginal nodule is the most specific marker of gestational choriocarcinoma. It is not seen in a case of invasive mole. Invasive mole is specifically associated with rupture of uterus causing hemoperitoneum.

questions.text: A 46 years old multiparous patient has dysmenorrhea as well as dyspareunia. Which one of the following is not the likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fibroid uterus

Dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia are seen in endometriosis, adenomyosis, PID and tuberculosis but dyspareunia is never seen in a case of fibroid uterus.

questions.text: At 25 years old patient is pregnant for the first time. She has full term gestation. She is in first stage of Labour. The segments involved in labour pain during first stage of Labour are?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

T10 to L1

The Labour pains are transmitted by T10, T11, T12 and L1 segments in first stage of labour while in second stage of labour, the transmission happens through S2, S3 and S4 segments.

questions.text: Which of the following patients should not undergo VBAC delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Past history of myomectomy of FIGO type 2-5 fibroid in the fundal region

Past history of myomectomy for a transmural fibroid in the fundal region would mean a scar of full thickness in the upper segment of uterus. High chance of rupture is seen in such cases hence vaginal delivery is not attempted in such cases.

questions.text: Which one of the following is an absolute contraindication for vacuum delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Face presentation

vacuum delivery can be done only if the presentation is vertex. vacuum is contraindicated on malpresentations like breech presentation, face presentation or brow presentation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological change in the carbohydrate metabolism in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fasting hyperglycemia

During pregnancy, there is increased insulin resistance caused by pregnancy hormones like HPL, estrogen, progesterone, testosterone, cortisol etc. These hormones tend to cause postprandial hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia. Physiologically, there is fasting hypoglycemia in pregnancy because of utilization of glucose by the fetus and hence fasting hyperglycemia is not a physiological change in pregnancy.

choices.text: Decrease in cardiac output immediately after delivery

questions.text: Regarding cardiovascular system physiological changes in pregnancy, which of the following statement is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decrease in systemic vascular resistance

During pregnancy, there is reduction in blood pressure caused by vasodilation. Cardiac output increases after delivery due to auto transfusion which means the blood from uterus will go into the systemic circulation. Hence, highest cardiac output is seen in immediate postpartum period. In pregnancy, there is vasodilation caused by progesterone and cytotrophoblast leading to reduction in systemic vascular resistance. Central venous pressure remains constant in pregnancy.

questions.text: Patient is suffering from hyperemesis gravidarum. Which of the following is possibly decreased?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A and B

In a case of hyperemesis gravidarum, there would be hypokalemia and hypoglycemia. There would be ketonemia caused due to starvation ketoacidosis.

questions.text: Routine Investigations done in a pregnant female are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ECG

Routine investigations would include hemoglobin, urine analysis, serology tests like HIV, HBsAg, VDRL and blood sugar evaluation by DIPSI test. We do not do ECG routinely in all pregnant patients

choices.text: Free T3 and T4 levels increase in pregnancy
Thyroid binding globulins are increased in pregnancy

questions.text: Which one of the following is physiologically seen regarding thyroid in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thyroid binding globulins are increased in pregnancy

Pregnancy is euthyroid condition. Free T3 and free T4 levels are normal. Thyroid binding globulins are increased in pregnancy due to estrogen. TSH level Is low normal due to HCG. Thyroid cell hyperplasia is seen but there is no goiter in pregnancy.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature of Sheehan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypertension

As discussed earlier, Sheehan syndrome is pituitary stalk necrosis caused due to hypoxia by PPH. It leads to lactational failure due to prolactin deficiency. There is hypoglycemia and hypotension due to ACTH deficiency. It leads to amenorrhea due to gonadotropin deficiency.

questions.text: Identify the given procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Zavanelli method

In this picture there is a procedure going on in which baby’s head is reposited back into the pelvis in order to do caesarean section. This method is called Zavanelli method. It is used to treat shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: Of the following, the electrolyte abnormality that is often found in infants born to women with diabetes mellitus is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hypocalcemia

Infants born to women with diabetes mellitus are at increased risk for hypocalcemia. This most likely results from a delay in the appropriate parathyroid hormone response after birth. Infants born to women with diabetes are also at risk for hypomagnesemia as a result of the decreased postnatal parathyroid hormone response and maternal hypomagnesemia from renal losses leading to decreased placental transfer of magnesium during gestation. Hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia usually occur within the first few days of life, especially if the infant has respiratory distress.

choices.text: Apply compressions over the upper third of the newborn’s sternum

questions.text: Of the following, the most appropriate technique to provide effective chest compressions in a newborn is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Compress to a depth one-third the anterior–posterior diameter of the chest
The current neonatal resuscitation guidelines for chest compressions include the following:
• Apply compressions over the lower third of the newborn’s sternum
• Compress to a depth one-third the anterior–posterior diameter of the chest
• Provide chest compressions and bag-mask breaths in a ratio of 3:1
• Use the two-thumb-encircling-hands approach instead of the two-finger technique when possible

choices.text: Biliary atresia is an uncommon cause of cholestasis in neonates.
Biliary atresia is the most common reason for a liver transplant in children.
The majority of infants with biliary atresia appear unhealthy, with poor growth at 3 to 6 weeks of age.
The majority of infants with biliary atresia have other congenital malformations.

questions.text: The pediatrician is concerned about a possible diagnosis of biliary atresia in a 4 weeks old baby, and consults with a pediatric surgeon. The surgeon performs a percutaneous liver biopsy that confirms this diagnosis. The surgeon then meets with the family to discuss this disease. Of the following, the most accurate statement about biliary atresia is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Biliary atresia is the most common reason for a liver transplant in children.

Biliary atresia is the most common cause of neonatal cholestasis. Most clinicians categorize biliary atresia into two types— the acquired form and the embryonic form. The acquired form is more common (~85%) and is associated with a significant inflammatory response involving the intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts, resulting in replacement of the ducts with fibrous scar tissue and eventual obliteration of the bile duct lumen.
Affected infants with this form typically appear healthy with a normal growth pattern and present in the first few weeks of life with jaundice, acholic stool, and dark urine. The embryonic form is less common (~15%) and is associated with other congenital malformations, such as heterotaxy syndrome and polysplenia. This group of neonates typically appears jaundiced soon after birth.
